title: At close of business on 12 December 2019, will the European Central Bank's (ECB's) deposit facility rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 24 October 2019?
preds: At close of business on 12 December 2019, will the European Central Bank's (ECB's) deposit facility rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 24 October 2019? Steady as she goes, no boat rocking allowed.
Not yet time to panic. Germany had positive GDP quarter, northern countries still resisting stimulation monetary policy. Probably do nothing yet. Watch for March.
Adjusting up. Time to assess impact of September change is too short. Growth is still anemic and Brexit uncertainty persists. Probably held onto my base rate too long on this one
Shifting a few points toward same as I don't see the bank wanting to rock the boat for the first meeting under Lagarde.

Interesting take.. https://www.fxstreet.com/news/ecb-to-cut-its-deposit-rate-by-10bp-in-march-abn-amro-201911111803 There are certainly  lot of factors that would point to the ECB cutting again in December. However, better than expected GDP growth and concerns about too deeply negative rates make a pause the base rate. I still think a cut is more likely than the 3% priced in by the consensus

At close of business on 12 December 2019, will the European Central Bank's (ECB's) deposit facility rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 24 October 2019? 
Hattip to @Emil for saying it better than I can. 
Steady as she goes while building consensus within before any changes in policy will take time.

The latest round of stimulus, implemented just before Lagarde took over in effect obviates the need for further policy decisions in the short term. [1] Additionally, Lagarde is contenting with increasingly vocal arguments from ECB members who opposed Draghi's expansionary policy [2]. What this suggests to me is that there will be internal debates within the ECB that will make a policy move less likely in the short term. With eurozone inflation still low, an increase to the rate seems extremely unlikely.  [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-28/christine-lagarde-faces-peril-on-all-sides-at-the-ecb
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/24/business/mario-draghi-ecb.html
The current rate was set recently and only after long decision making and deliberation. Even with a new leader, I don't believe the rate will change so soon.

My inside view: The rate will not change. Both the out going and in coming presidents are clear, member states with large surpluses must use this to reinvest in their ecomonies. Perhaps signalling no more ECB stimulus until 2020. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-30/lagarde-takes-up-draghi-s-plea-for-fiscal-support-in-europe

I'm revising my forecast in view of the following: 1) The ECB decided to lower the deposit rate from 0.4 to 0.5 following a period of almost 4 years. That would infer the decision to do so was measured and not taken lightly. This, parallel to the average decrease of once per year before 2016, perhaps supports no change in December 2019. 2) Both the monetary policy board and ECB governing council members were against lowering the deposit rate further. It exhausts remaining measures/stimulus to respond to developing situations; deterring possible investment and increasing risk practices in the financial market for higher yields. 3) The outgoing President stated that Governments must do more. With particular focus on Germany, largest ecomony in the EU, and the possibility of a recession. ECB Stimulus will only achieve so much with market conditions, such as trade wars, Brexit, and a global trend of slow growth, working against it. 4) The in coming President, Lagarde is reported to be a consensus builder. With a leaning towards political beneficial policies. As stated above, there significant disagreement regarding reducing the rate further and using QE easing. The out going President used his position to force it through. Lagarde may then seek to reconcile the governing council, reducing the probability of further cuts. My forecast then is 0 probability of a higher rate increase; 92 % probability of remaining the same; a negliable probability of being lowered further at 8 %.
The new governor, will most likely commit no change at her first Monetary Metting that she will head

I'll add my working later, wanted to get my forecast in early though. Agree with the consensus. That there is a low probability the deposit rate will rise. With a combination of factors, discussed in detail by others below, increasing the probability of the rate will remain the same. - 0.5 is a historic low, there was significant disagreement regarding its implementation through out the Governing Council Meeting: https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/accounts/2019/html/ecb.mg191010~d8086505d0.en.htm September to December is not a sufficient period to evaulaute the effects of QE programmes. This, parallel to the view that these measures will be limited in their effectiveness, makes my forecast favour the rate being the same.

https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pr/date/2019/html/ecb.mp191024~438769bd4f.en.html "The Governing Council expects the key ECB interest rates to remain at their present or lower levels until it has seen the inflation outlook robustly converge to a level sufficiently close to, but below, 2% within its projection horizon, and such convergence has been consistently reflected in underlying inflation dynamics." Factors in favour of Same over Lower:
- political resistance to further cuts (particularly from Germany)
- the deposit facility rate isn't the only policy tool the ECB is making use of (asset purchases have restarted)

Since 1999 the ECB has met 95 times (every 6 weeks) and have cut rates in 23 of those meetings (24%) and raised rates in 21 (22%). As a result, the outside view would be .24, .54, .22 That being said, the Eurozone is a much different place now. Brexit, persistently low inflation, 10 years of easing, debt crises, economic and political polarization (between North and South), etc. all make an tightening seem less than likely. As recession risks pick up, I think monetary policy will continue to ease in an effort to support the economy. However, macro policy takes time (about 6 months in the US) to impact the economy, so the likelihood of further loosening seems low until the ECB can assess the impact. Potential risks are most likely to be Brexit (the proposed election will take place on that 12/12) or further escalation of the US - China trade war.  All these considerations are pulling the “Higher” probability from my base rate into the “Same” bucket. I don’t have a ton of reason to move from the “Lower” bucket except for the fact that I don’t think there’s enough time to see the impact of the September cut.  Lower: 21%
Same: 75%
Higher: 4%

Potential base rate:
In the past six years, the ECB has lowered rates 5 times, so less than once per year. [1] The forward guidance states interest rates will stay at or below current levels until inflation picks up. [2,3] In my opinion, the ECB faces pressure to provide further economic stimulus when they might be reaching a threshold at which the impact of negative interest rates will become more (publicly) apparent. Christine Lagarde taking over as president in my view increases the probability of lowering interest rates. Lagarde is regarded to be more likely to give weight to political arguments (supporting rate cuts to stimulate growth and helping highly indebted eurozone countries) rather than economic arguments (highlighting the dangers of prolonged significantly negative interest rates and inability to react to potential economic downturns). [1] https://www.ecb.europa.eu/stats/policy_and_exchange_rates/key_ecb_interest_rates/html/index.en.html
[2] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/24/ecb-keeps-rates-unchanged-as-mario-draghi-says-goodbye-to-frankfurt.html
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/ecb-policy-textiles/text-ecb-statement-after-policy-meeting-idUSL5N2796BT
